1f:T9cd,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Recipe","name":"Dulce de Leche","description":"Argentina's national confection — slow-cooked caramelized milk that's used in everything from alfajores to ice cream to eating straight from the jar with a spoon. Making it from scratch takes patience but the result is incomparably better than store-bought.","image":"https://expatsargentina.com/images/recipes/dulce-de-leche.webp","author":{"@type":"Organization","name":"Expats Argentina"},"datePublished":"2025-01-01","prepTime":"PT5M","cookTime":"PT3M","totalTime":"PT8M","recipeYield":"16 servings","recipeCategory":"dessert","recipeCuisine":"Argentine","keywords":"dulce de leche recipe, homemade dulce de leche, argentine caramel, how to make dulce de leche, dulce de leche from scratch","nutrition":{"@type":"NutritionInformation","calories":"120 calories","proteinContent":"3g","carbohydrateContent":"20g","fatContent":"3g"},"recipeIngredient":["Stovetop method: 1 liter (4 cups) whole milk","Stovetop method: 300g (1.5 cups) white sugar","Stovetop method: 1 tsp vanilla extract","Stovetop method: 1/2 tsp baking soda dissolved in 1 tbsp water","Stovetop method: Pinch of salt"],"recipeInstructions":[{"@type":"HowToStep","position":1,"text":"Combine milk, sugar, and salt in a large, heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":2,"text":"Stir constantly until the sugar dissolves completely."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":3,"text":"When the mixture begins to simmer, add the baking soda mixture — it will foam up, this is normal."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":4,"text":"Reduce heat to low. The mixture should barely simmer — tiny bubbles, not a rolling boil."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":5,"text":"Stir every 10-15 minutes, scraping the bottom and sides to prevent sticking."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":6,"text":"After about 1.5 hours, the mixture will start to thicken and turn golden. Stir more frequently now."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":7,"text":"Continue cooking for another 1-1.5 hours, stirring constantly in the final 30 minutes."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":8,"text":"The dulce de leche is ready when it's thick, deeply caramel-colored, and coats the back of a spoon."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":9,"text":"Add vanilla extract and stir well."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":10,"text":"Remove from heat and let cool. It will thicken further as it cools."},{"@type":"HowToStep","position":11,"text":"Transfer to clean glass jars."}]}17:["$","div",null,{"className":"min-h-screen bg-gradient-to-b from-orange-50 to-white","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$1f"}}],["$","div",null,{"className":"border-b bg-white/80 backdrop-blur-sm sticky top-0 z-40 print:hidden","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-5xl mx-auto px-4 py-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-center justify-between","children":["$","$L6",null,{"href":"/food/recipes","children":[["$","svg",null,{"ref":"$undefined","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-arrow-left w-4 h-4","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1l729n",{"d":"m12 19-7-7 7-7"}],["$","path","x3x0zl",{"d":"M19 12H5"}],"$undefined"]}],"All Recipes"],"data-slot":"button","data-variant":"ghost","data-size":"sm","className":"inline-flex items-center justify-center whitespace-nowrap text-sm font-medium transition-all disabled:pointer-events-none disabled:opacity-50 [&_svg]:pointer-events-none [&_svg:not([class*='size-'])]:size-4 shrink-0 [&_svg]:shrink-0 outline-none focus-visible:border-ring focus-visible:ring-ring/50 focus-visible:ring-[3px] aria-invalid:ring-destructive/20 dark:aria-invalid:ring-destructive/40 aria-invalid:border-destructive hover:bg-accent hover:text-accent-foreground dark:hover:bg-accent/50 h-8 rounded-md px-3 has-[>svg]:px-2.5 gap-2","ref":null}]}]}]}],"$L20","$L21","$L22"]}]

2d:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm bg-gradient-to-br from-amber-50 to-orange-50 border-amber-100 print:bg-none print:border-gray-300","id":"tips","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-2 text-xl","children":[["$","svg",null,{"ref":"$undefined","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-lightbulb w-5 h-5 text-amber-600","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1gvzjb",{"d":"M15 14c.2-1 .7-1.7 1.5-2.5 1-.9 1.5-2.2 1.5-3.5A6 6 0 0 0 6 8c0 1 .2 2.2 1.5 3.5.7.7 1.3 1.5 1.5 2.5"}],["$","path","x1upvd",{"d":"M9 18h6"}],["$","path","ceow96",{"d":"M10 22h4"}],"$undefined"]}],"Pro Tips from the Kitchen"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","ul",null,{"className":"space-y-3","children":[["$","li","0",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Low and slow is the absolute key. High heat will burn the bottom and give a bitter taste."}]]}],["$","li","1",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"The baking soda helps with color development and prevents the milk proteins from curdling."}]]}],["$","li","2",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Test doneness by dropping a small amount on a cold plate — it should hold its shape without spreading."}]]}],["$","li","3",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"If you want a shortcut, you can simmer an unopened can of condensed milk in water for 3 hours — but homemade is noticeably better."}]]}],["$","li","4",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Stir with a wooden spoon — metal can react with the milk acids."}]]}],["$","li","5",{"className":"flex items-start gap-3","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"text-amber-500 mt-1","children":"✦"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"The color should be deep amber, not dark brown. If it gets too dark, it will be bitter."}]]}]]}]}]]}]
2e:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","id":"history","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold flex items-center gap-2 text-xl","children":[["$","svg",null,{"ref":"$undefined","xmlns":"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg","width":24,"height":24,"viewBox":"0 0 24 24","fill":"none","stroke":"currentColor","strokeWidth":2,"strokeLinecap":"round","strokeLinejoin":"round","className":"lucide lucide-history w-5 h-5 text-orange-600","aria-hidden":"true","children":[["$","path","1357e3",{"d":"M3 12a9 9 0 1 0 9-9 9.75 9.75 0 0 0-6.74 2.74L3 8"}],["$","path","1xhq8a",{"d":"M3 3v5h5"}],["$","path","1fdv2h",{"d":"M12 7v5l4 2"}],"$undefined"]}],"The Story Behind the Dish"]}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700 leading-relaxed","children":"Dulce de leche's origin is disputed between Argentina and Uruguay, but both countries claim it as their own. The most popular origin story involves a maid who accidentally left a pot of milk and sugar on the fire in 1829 while making lechada for General Rosas. When she returned, the mixture had caramelized into dulce de leche. Argentines consume over 3 kg per person per year — it's in alfajores, pancakes, ice cream, cakes, and eaten by the spoonful."}]}]]}]
2f:["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm print:shadow-none print:border-gray-300","children":[["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-header","className":"@container/card-header grid auto-rows-min grid-rows-[auto_auto] items-start gap-2 px-6 has-data-[slot=card-action]:grid-cols-[1fr_auto] [.border-b]:pb-6 pb-3","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-title","className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Storage & Leftovers"}]}],["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-0","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-gray-700","children":"Store in sealed glass jars in the refrigerator for up to 3 weeks. Can also be frozen for up to 3 months. Bring to room temperature before using for easier spreading."}]}]]}]
1c:[["$","meta","0",{"charSet":"utf-8"}],["$","meta","1",{"name":"viewport","content":"width=device-width, initial-scale=1"}]]
30:I[17124,["/_next/static/chunks/f7a6a5c10098787e.js","/_next/static/chunks/0228e4c449c3a8b8.js"],"IconMark"]
1a:null
1e:[["$","title","0",{"children":"Dulce de Leche | Authentic Argentine Recipe | Expats Argentina | Expats Argentina"}],["$","meta","1",{"name":"description","content":"Argentina's national confection — slow-cooked caramelized milk that's used in everything from alfajores to ice cream to eating straight from the jar with a spoon. Making it from scratch takes patience but the result is incomparably better than store-bought. Prep time: 5 min. Serves 16."}],["$","meta","2",{"name":"author","content":"Expats Argentina"}],["$","meta","3",{"name":"keywords","content":"dulce de leche recipe,homemade dulce de leche,argentine caramel,how to make dulce de leche,dulce de leche from scratch"}],["$","meta","4",{"name":"creator","content":"Expats Argentina"}],["$","meta","5",{"name":"robots","content":"index, follow"}],["$","meta","6",{"name":"googlebot","content":"index, follow, max-video-preview:-1, max-image-preview:large, max-snippet:-1"}],["$","meta","7",{"name":"theme-color","content":"#0d9488"}],["$","meta","8",{"name":"apple-mobile-web-app-status-bar-style","content":"default"}],["$","link","9",{"rel":"canonical","href":"https://expatsargentina.com/food/recipes/dulce-de-leche/"}],["$","meta","10",{"property":"og:title","content":"Dulce de Leche | Authentic Argentine Recipe"}],["$","meta","11",{"property":"og:description","content":"Argentina's national confection — slow-cooked caramelized milk that's used in everything from alfajores to ice cream to eating straight from the jar with a spoon.
